Platform.Title: USDA-ARS-PSMRU-SalmonellaTEv4
Platform.Manufacturer: Produce Safety and Microbiology, USDA-ARS, Albany, CA
Platform.Manufacture-Protocol: PCR product microarray of ORF's from S. Typhimurium LT2 and S. Enteritidis PT4. PCR products resuspended to an average concentration of 0.1-0.2 µg µl-1 in 20 µl of 50% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) containing 0.3× Saline-Sodium Citrate (SSC). Spotted on Corning barcoded UltraGAPS slides using a GeneMachine Accent printer with ChipMaker pins.

Sample.Title: MB282 + Tet 1-29-09 technical rep 1

Channel.Source: MB282 co cultured with Tetrahymena in H2O for 3 hours at 28 deg C 1-29-09
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
MB282 was bound within the Tetrahymena food vacuole (phagosome)
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Eight co-cultures of 50 mL were centrifuged at 800 x g for 2 min. The resulting pellet was enriched for Tetrahymena cells containing ingested SL1344 since most uningested free bacteria were not pelleted and remained in suspension. The supernatant was quickly removed and the pellet was resuspended in ice cold lysis buffer (0.5% SDS, 19% ethanol and 1% phenol in H2O). The suspension containing lysed Tetrahymena was centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min at 4 ºC. The bacterial pellet was then stored at -80ºC until RNA extraction. RNA extraction was performed with the Promega SV Total RNA Isolation kit per the manufacturer’s specifications, except that bacterial pellets were first treated with 50 mg/mL of lysozyme (Fisherbrand). RNA from two different sources was used as control. The first control RNA was isolated from 50 mL of SL1344 cells incubated in sterile H2O at an OD600 of 0.2 for 3 h, similarly to the SL1344 cells mixed with Tetrahymena. The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Channel.Source: MB282 genomic DNA
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
genomic DNA served as reference signal
Channel.Extract-Protocol: 3 mL of Salmonella enterica SL1344 (MB282) was grown overnight in LB broth to stationary phase. The culture was centrifuged at 11400 x G for 3 minutes in a bench top microcentrifuge. After removing the supernatant, Promega Wizard® Genomic DNA Purification Kit was used to extract DNA from the cell pellet using the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quality was assessed using the Nanodrop® ND-1000 Spectrophotometer.
Channel.Label: Cy5
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: DNA was crossed–linked to slides by UV radiation. All cDNA solutions were adjusted to the same label concentration and were hybridized to the arrays overnight at 42ºC. For each experimental condition, cDNA was prepared from three replicate suspensions (biological replicates) and each cDNA was hybridized to three replicate arrays (technical replicates) at random among several slides.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: Slides were washed and then scanned with a Genepix 4000b scanner and Genepix Pro 4.1 software (Axon Instruments).
Sample.Description: Whole genome S. enterica LT2 arrays were prepared at the USDA Western Regional Research Center. Each array contained 4360 PCR-generated ORFs (including 104 from virulence plasmid pSLT). Reference 1: Eriksson S, Lucchini S, Thompson A, Rhen M, Hinton JC. (2003) Unravelling the biology of macrophage infection by gene expression profiling of intracellular Salmonella enterica. Mol Microbio. 47:103-18. Reference 2: Kyle JL, Parker CT, Goudeau D, Brandl MT. (2010). Transcriptome Analysis of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 exposed to lysates of lettuce leaves. Appl Environ Microbiol 76:1375-1387.
Sample.Data-Processing: To address spatial dye effects or any disparity in amounts of spotted cDNA, data were normalized by setting the median log (Cy3/Cy5 ratio) of all of the spots on the same array to zero. Prior to analysis by Genespring, outliers among technical replicates were eliminated from the analysis with Dixon’s Q Test (critical value of 0.1) and remaining data were averaged.

The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: DNA was crossed–linked to slides by UV radiation. All cDNA solutions were adjusted to the same label concentration and were hybridized to the arrays overnight at 42ºC. After removing the supernatant, Promega Wizard® Genomic DNA Purification Kit was used to extract DNA from the cell pellet using the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quality was assessed using the Nanodrop® ND-1000 Spectrophotometer.
Channel.Label: Cy5
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: DNA was crossed–linked to slides by UV radiation. All cDNA solutions were adjusted to the same label concentration and were hybridized to the arrays overnight at 42ºC. For each experimental condition, cDNA was prepared from three replicate suspensions (biological replicates) and each cDNA was hybridized to three replicate arrays (technical replicates) at random among several slides.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: Slides were washed and then scanned with a Genepix 4000b scanner and Genepix Pro 4.1 software (Axon Instruments).
Sample.Description: Whole genome S. enterica LT2 arrays were prepared at the USDA Western Regional Research Center. Each array contained 4360 PCR-generated ORFs (including 104 from virulence plasmid pSLT). Reference 1: Eriksson S, Lucchini S, Thompson A, Rhen M, Hinton JC. (2003) Unravelling the biology of macrophage infection by gene expression profiling of intracellular Salmonella enterica. Mol Microbio. 47:103-18. Reference 2: Kyle JL, Parker CT, Goudeau D, Brandl MT. (2010). Transcriptome Analysis of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 exposed to lysates of lettuce leaves. Appl Environ Microbiol 76:1375-1387.
Sample.Data-Processing: To address spatial dye effects or any disparity in amounts of spotted cDNA, data were normalized by setting the median log (Cy3/Cy5 ratio) of all of the spots on the same array to zero. Prior to analysis by Genespring, outliers among technical replicates were eliminated from the analysis with Dixon’s Q Test (critical value of 0.1) and remaining data were averaged.

Sample.Title: MB282 H2O 4-9-09C techical rep 1

Channel.Source: MB282 incubated in H2O for 3 hours at 28 deg C 4-9-09C
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
MB282 was incubated axenically in H2O, this served as a control
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Eight co-cultures of 50 mL were centrifuged at 800 x g for 2 min. The resulting pellet was enriched for Tetrahymena cells containing ingested SL1344 since most uningested free bacteria were not pelleted and remained in suspension. The supernatant was quickly removed and the pellet was resuspended in ice cold lysis buffer (0.5% SDS, 19% ethanol and 1% phenol in H2O). The suspension containing lysed Tetrahymena was centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min at 4 ºC. The bacterial pellet was then stored at -80ºC until RNA extraction. RNA extraction was performed with the Promega SV Total RNA Isolation kit per the manufacturer’s specifications, except that bacterial pellets were first treated with 50 mg/mL of lysozyme (Fisherbrand). RNA from two different sources was used as control. The first control RNA was isolated from 50 mL of SL1344 cells incubated in sterile H2O at an OD600 of 0.2 for 3 h, similarly to the SL1344 cells mixed with Tetrahymena. The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.

Reference 2: Kyle JL, Parker CT, Goudeau D, Brandl MT. (2010). Transcriptome Analysis of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 exposed to lysates of lettuce leaves. Appl Environ Microbiol 76:1375-1387.
Sample.Data-Processing: To address spatial dye effects or any disparity in amounts of spotted cDNA, data were normalized by setting the median log (Cy3/Cy5 ratio) of all of the spots on the same array to zero. Prior to analysis by Genespring, outliers among technical replicates were eliminated from the analysis with Dixon’s Q Test (critical value of 0.1) and remaining data were averaged.

Sample.Title: MB282 LB 2-19-09 technical rep 1

Channel.Source: MB282 grown to mid-log phase in LB broth at 28 deg C 2-19-09
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
MB282 was grown in LB to an OD of 0.4 - 0.6, this served as a control
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Eight co-cultures of 50 mL were centrifuged at 800 x g for 2 min. The resulting pellet was enriched for Tetrahymena cells containing ingested SL1344 since most uningested free bacteria were not pelleted and remained in suspension. The supernatant was quickly removed and the pellet was resuspended in ice cold lysis buffer (0.5% SDS, 19% ethanol and 1% phenol in H2O). The suspension containing lysed Tetrahymena was centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min at 4 ºC. The bacterial pellet was then stored at -80ºC until RNA extraction. RNA extraction was performed with the Promega SV Total RNA Isolation kit per the manufacturer’s specifications, except that bacterial pellets were first treated with 50 mg/mL of lysozyme (Fisherbrand). RNA from two different sources was used as control. The first control RNA was isolated from 50 mL of SL1344 cells incubated in sterile H2O at an OD600 of 0.2 for 3 h, similarly to the SL1344 cells mixed with Tetrahymena. The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

RNA extraction was performed with the Promega SV Total RNA Isolation kit per the manufacturer’s specifications, except that bacterial pellets were first treated with 50 mg/mL of lysozyme (Fisherbrand). RNA from two different sources was used as control. The first control RNA was isolated from 50 mL of SL1344 cells incubated in sterile H2O at an OD600 of 0.2 for 3 h, similarly to the SL1344 cells mixed with Tetrahymena. The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.
Channel.Label: Cy3
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Channel.Source: MB282 genomic DNA
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
genomic DNA served as reference signal
Channel.Extract-Protocol: 3 mL of Salmonella enterica SL1344 (MB282) was grown overnight in LB broth to stationary phase. The culture was centrifuged at 11400 x G for 3 minutes in a bench top microcentrifuge. After removing the supernatant, Promega Wizard® Genomic DNA Purification Kit was used to extract DNA from the cell pellet using the manufacturer's protocol. DNA quality was assessed using the Nanodrop® ND-1000 Spectrophotometer.
Channel.Label: Cy5
Channel.Label-Protocol: Preparation of labeled nucleotides and hybridization to arrays was carried out as described previously (Kyle et al., 2010) based on the method developed by Eriksson et al. (2003). Briefly, 20µg RNA from co-cultures and controls was reverse transcribed and Cy3-dCTP (GE Healthcare) incorporated into cDNA using the Fairplay III Microarray Labeling Kit (Stratagene). 2 µg of SL1344 genomic DNA was labeled with Cy5-dCTP (GE Healthcare) using Klenow (New England Biolabs) and served as the reference signal on the arrays. Labeling efficiency was determined with a Nanodrop 2000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific).

Sample.Hybridization-Protocol: DNA was crossed–linked to slides by UV radiation. All cDNA solutions were adjusted to the same label concentration and were hybridized to the arrays overnight at 42ºC. For each experimental condition, cDNA was prepared from three replicate suspensions (biological replicates) and each cDNA was hybridized to three replicate arrays (technical replicates) at random among several slides.
Sample.Scan-Protocol: Slides were washed and then scanned with a Genepix 4000b scanner and Genepix Pro 4.1 software (Axon Instruments).
Sample.Description: Whole genome S. enterica LT2 arrays were prepared at the USDA Western Regional Research Center. Each array contained 4360 PCR-generated ORFs (including 104 from virulence plasmid pSLT). Reference 1: Eriksson S, Lucchini S, Thompson A, Rhen M, Hinton JC. (2003) Unravelling the biology of macrophage infection by gene expression profiling of intracellular Salmonella enterica. Mol Microbio. 47:103-18. Reference 2: Kyle JL, Parker CT, Goudeau D, Brandl MT. (2010). Transcriptome Analysis of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 exposed to lysates of lettuce leaves. Appl Environ Microbiol 76:1375-1387.
Sample.Data-Processing: To address spatial dye effects or any disparity in amounts of spotted cDNA, data were normalized by setting the median log (Cy3/Cy5 ratio) of all of the spots on the same array to zero. Prior to analysis by Genespring, outliers among technical replicates were eliminated from the analysis with Dixon’s Q Test (critical value of 0.1) and remaining data were averaged.

Sample.Title: MB282 LB 4-15-09C technical rep 2

Channel.Source: MB282 grown to mid-log phase in LB broth at 28 deg C 4-15-09C
Channel.Characteristics: Typhimurium MB282
MB282 was grown in LB to an OD of 0.4 - 0.6, this served as a control
Channel.Extract-Protocol: Eight co-cultures of 50 mL were centrifuged at 800 x g for 2 min. The resulting pellet was enriched for Tetrahymena cells containing ingested SL1344 since most uningested free bacteria were not pelleted and remained in suspension. The supernatant was quickly removed and the pellet was resuspended in ice cold lysis buffer (0.5% SDS, 19% ethanol and 1% phenol in H2O). The suspension containing lysed Tetrahymena was centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min at 4 ºC. The bacterial pellet was then stored at -80ºC until RNA extraction. The second control RNA was isolated from 20 mL of SL1344 cells grown to mid–log phase of growth in LB broth. Both suspensions were centrifuged at 3200 x g for 5 min. at 4 ºC followed by addition of lysis buffer and centrifugation as described above. Bacterial pellets were immediately stored at -80ºC. Three biological replicates were used for each type of suspension. RNA integrity was assessed with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and only RNA of high quality was used for microarray hybridizations and RT-qPCR.

Series.Title: Gene expression analysis of S. Typhimurium cells residing in the food vacuole (phagosome) of the bacteria grazing ciliate Tetrahymena
Series.Summary: The gene expression of Salmonella enterica Typhimurium MB282 residing in the food vacuole (phagosome) of Tetrahymena was analyzed by microarray.
Series.Overall-Design: A minimum of three biological replicates were used. Each biological rep was comprised of at least two technical replicate arrays. MB282 incubated in H2O and MB282 grown to mid - log in LB were used as controls.
